div.l: For ielous folke ben perlious euermoo
Algates thei wolde her wyues wende soo
And eke for shee was somdele smoterliche
She was as digne as water in a diche
As fulle of hoker and of bysmare
Hir thought that a lady shulde hir spare
What for hir kinrede and hir nurtilrye
That she had lerned in the nunrye
A doughter had thei a twix hem twoo
Of twenty yere withouten eny moo
Sauynge a childe that was of halfe yere age
In cradell it lay and was a ꝓpropre page
This wenche thikke and well growen was
With cammoys nose and yien grey as glas
With buttokkes brode and brestes rounde and hye
But right feire was hir here I will nat lye
The ꝑpersonne of the toun̄ for she was feire
In purpoos was too make hir his heire
Both of his catell and of his messuage
And straunge he made it of hir mariage
His p~urpoos was for to bestowe hir hie
In to sōmme worthy blode of Auncetrye
For holy chirch gode muste be dispended
On holy chirch blode that is descended
Therfore he wolde his holy blode honoure
Though that he holy chirch shulde deuoure
Grete souken hath this miller out of doute
With whete and malte of all the londe aboute
And namelich there was a grete college
Men clepe the scoler hall of Cambrigge
There was hir whete and her malte y grounde
And on a day it happed in a stounde
Sike laye the maunciple in a maledye
Menne wende wisely that he shulde dye
For whiche he stale both mele and corne
An hundred tyme more thenne beforne
For there before he stale but curteislye
But nowe he was a thefe outrageouslye
For which the wardeyne chidde and made fare
But there of sette the miller nat a tare
He crakked booste and swore itte was nat soo
Thenne were there yonge scolers twoo
That dwelled in the halle which I seye
Testyf they were and lusty for to pleye
And onely for their myrth and ryuery
Vpon the warden besely they crye
To yeve hem leve but a litle stounde
Too goone to mylle and seene her corne y grounde
And hardely they durste leyn her nekke
The miller shulde nat stele hem halfe a pekke
Of corne ne mele by force hem bireve
And at the laste the wardein yave him leve
Iohn hight that one and alleyn hight that other
Of oo toun̄ were they borne that hight strother
Ferre in the northe I canne nat tellen where
This aleyne maketh redy all his gere
And on an hors the sakke he caste anone
Forth goth Aleyn the clerke and alsoo Iohn
With goode swerde and bokeler by her side
Iohn knewe the wey him neded no gyde
And at the mille the sakke adoun̄ he leith
Aleyn spake ferste all haille Symonde he seith
Howe fares thy feire doughter and thy wife
Aleyn welcom̄e quoth symken by my life
And Iohn alsoo howe nowe what doo ye here
By god quoth Iohn . Symonde nede hath no pere
Him behoueth to serve him self that hath no swayne
Or elles he is a foole as clerkes seyne
Oure maunciple I trowe he wolle be dede
Swa werkes ay the wanges in his hede
And therfore am I com̄e and eke Aleyn
To grynde oure corne and cary it hame ageyn
I pray you spede vs hens what ye may
It shalle be done quoth symkyn by my fay
What will ye done while that it is in hande
By god right by the hoper woll I stande
